FacilityName: Auglaize Farmers Cooperative, Inc. - St. Marys

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Auglaize Farmers Cooperative, Inc. - St. Marys
RMP Executive Summary - Anhydrous Ammonia


1.  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy
                                                                                                                                                                                       The owners, management, and employees are committed to the prevention of accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, county LEPC, EPA, and other applicable authorities to mitigate the release and minimize its impact on people and the environment.

2.  Facility and Regulated Substance Handled  

The primary activity at this facility is the storage and blending of fertilizers for sale to farmers.  Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as a fertilizer for crop production. 

3.  Accidental Release Prevention Program

This facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1", published by The American National Standards Institute (ANSI), and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".  The facility has also complied with the Ohio Department of Agriculture "Regulations For Storing And Handling Fertilizer Anhydrous Ammonia".

4.  Five-Year Accident History

There has been one accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years.  The incident was due to a valve on a 1000 gallon nurse tank leaking a small amount of vapor, which drifted into an open door of a near-by factory within the alternate release distance.  The incident resulted in one factory employee with a history of asthma being treated at a near-by hospital, and released to return to work.  The tank contained only a residue of product, and the amount of release was n

ot measureable.  As corrective action the valve was tightened, company emergency numbers were given to the factory safety director, and the manager instructed that all nurse tanks should be parked at the back of the property away from the more populated area.   

5.  Emergency Response Program

The facility has: 
-a written Emergency Action Plan in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38.
-a written Emergency Response Plan in accordance with OSHA standard, 1910.120, including pre-emergency planning and employee training.  
-provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA).

6.  Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Safety improvement is an on-going process at this facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed by company personnel and by the Ohio Department of Agriculture to assess the safety of equipment and procedures.  There are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementation as this time.
